content.raw:
Is the terminal you launched from displaying any errors \(i.e. cannot find a model\)?  This could be related to levels being turned on now so only parts of the environment being used by your robot will load.

I saw something similar from my log back from Cloudsim but I also had a ton of errors about can’t find specific models. I’m working on reproducing that issue with local Cloudsim.

content.raw:
Hmm, @{5cf75629ff02b50ea27b2817} will be the one that might have the answer about that triangular color warning.  

Depending on whether or not recording is turned on you'll have logs from Gazebo in \(~/.ignition/gazebo/log/<timestamp>\) and you can view them by using the command \(ign gazebo --playback ~/.ignition/gazebo/log/<timestamp>\).  If you submitted an image to the Cloudsim you'll have to download the logs, extract them, and then run \(ign gazebo --playback <path\_to\_directory\_with\_logs>\).
content.html:
Hmm, @Alfredo Bencomo will be the one that might have the answer about that triangular color warning.

Depending on whether or not recording is turned on you'll have logs from Gazebo in (~/.ignition/gazebo/log/<timestamp>) and you can view them by using the command (ign gazebo --playback ~/.ignition/gazebo/log/<timestamp>). If you submitted an image to the Cloudsim you'll have to download the logs, extract them, and then run (ign gazebo --playback <path_to_directory_with_logs>).

@{557058:c8cb9f24-90aa-4ffe-ac4f-4da0589ec56f} , can you clear your model cache and try loading the world again? You can clear it like this:

```
rm -rf ~/.ignition/fuel
```

If the problem persists, can you share your console output so we can search for other erros?

Is your problem only with `tunnel_circuit_practice_03` or also with the other 2 practice worlds?

content.raw:
@Lý Nguyễn, please let’s us know if works after clearing the cache and re-run it.

Notice that if you are using the latest [Docker image](https://hub.docker.com/r/nkoenig/subt-virtual-testbed) or updated your [catkin workspace](#!/osrf/subt/wiki/tutorials/SystemSetupInstall), then you will not see the entire tunnel world displayed at launching since we are now uploading levels dynamically \(on demand\), as shown [here](https://vimeo.com/349568034).
content.html:
@Lý Nguyễn, please let’s us know if works after clearing the cache and re-run it.

Notice that if you are using the latest Docker image or updated your catkin workspace, then you will not see the entire tunnel world displayed at launching since we are now uploading levels dynamically (on demand), as shown here.

content.raw:
I'm getting the same result as @{5cf560a5c90d790e902d5ed6} , the message shows up, but I can still teleoperate.

According to [this](https://github.com/ros-drivers/joystick_drivers/issues/134#issuecomment-507338762), "_The error is non-fatal - i.e., it can be ignored. It's just telling you that it failed to enable force-feedback because it is not available on your controller. Everything else should work fine._". Sounds like it should be a warning :slight_smile:
content.html:
I'm getting the same result as @Derek Knowles , the message shows up, but I can still teleoperate.

According to this, "The error is non-fatal - i.e., it can be ignored. It's just telling you that it failed to enable force-feedback because it is not available on your controller. Everything else should work fine.". Sounds like it should be a warning

content.raw:
@{557058:c8cb9f24-90aa-4ffe-ac4f-4da0589ec56f}, did you use give a custom name to your robots when you launched your simulation? On your initial post you listed `robotName1:=X1`, but this issue has pivoted so much already that I'm not sure that's still your setup.

It looks like the joystick teleoperation isn't supposed to support custom robot names, it's just meant for debugging a few robots at a time. So could you try launching with `robotName1:=X1` and see if that fixes your joystick issue?

---

If you really want to use custom names, you can build `subt_examples` from source, changing the [config](#!/osrf/subt/src/default/subt_example/config/robot_config.yaml) file to match your robot's name, i.e.

```.diff
+++ b/subt_example/config/robot_config.yaml     Sat Jul 27 16:19:22 2019 -0700
@@ -1,11 +1,11 @@
 robot_names:
-  - X1
+  - X1_C1
   - X2
   - X3
   - X4
 
 button_robot_map:
-  A: X1
+  A: X1_C1
   B: X2
   X: X3
   Y: X4
@@ -22,7 +22,7 @@
   - /right_flashlight/enable
 
 robot_address_map:
-  X1: X1
+  X1: X1_C1
   X2: X2
   X3: X3
   X4: X4
```
content.html:
@Lý Nguyễn, did you use give a custom name to your robots when you launched your simulation? On your initial post you listed robotName1:=X1, but this issue has pivoted so much already that I'm not sure that's still your setup.

It looks like the joystick teleoperation isn't supposed to support custom robot names, it's just meant for debugging a few robots at a time. So could you try launching with robotName1:=X1 and see if that fixes your joystick issue?

If you really want to use custom names, you can build subt_examples from source, changing the config file to match your robot's name, i.e.

+++ b/subt_example/config/robot_config.yaml     Sat Jul 27 16:19:22 2019 -0700
@@ -1,11 +1,11 @@
 robot_names:
-  - X1
+  - X1_C1
   - X2
   - X3
   - X4

 button_robot_map:
-  A: X1
+  A: X1_C1
   B: X2
   X: X3
   Y: X4
@@ -22,7 +22,7 @@
   - /right_flashlight/enable

 robot_address_map:
-  X1: X1
+  X1: X1_C1
   X2: X2
   X3: X3
   X4: X4
